title: Chancellor schedules first post-Brexit Budget for November 6th
text:
Chancellor Sajid Javid revealed on Monday that he plans to deliver Britain's first post-Brexit Budget on Wednesday 6th November - just a few days after the UK's deadline for leaving the European Union.

In a statement, Javid said: 'I will be setting out our plan to shape the economy for the future and triggering the start of our infrastructure revolution.'

However, the speech will only go ahead if the country exits with a deal.

Chancellor Sajid Javid revealed on Monday that he plans to deliver Britain's first post-Brexit budget statement on November 6

In a no-deal scenario, the Government said it will 'take early action to support the economy, businesses and households', followed by a budget in the weeks after.

Despite legislation to force a delay and prevent no deal, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is still arguing that he will take Britain out of the EU on October 31, with or without a deal.

The pound surged on Friday, enjoying its steepest 2-day climb in a decade, as gloomy investors became more optimistic about a breakthrough in Brexit negotiations.

However, the currency pared back gains in early trading on Monday after officials in the talks admitted that 'a lot of work remains to be done'.

David Cheetham from XTB said that the currency's 'almost euphoric' reaction to positive remarks from the EU last week on the prospect of a Brexit deal 'has been checked a little'.

'Over the weekend there was some less positive noises out of Brussels with one EU diplomat stating that there was 'no breakthrough yet' and another going further in claiming that today's talks would the the 'one last chance' for an agreement,' he said.

The pound has tumbled 0.7% against both the dollar and the euro on Monday morning

At time of writing, the pound was down 0.7 per cent against the dollar at $1.2557 and the same against the euro at €1.1375.

Shadow finance chief John McDonnell said that Javid's budget announcement, if it goes ahead, would likely be aimed at wooing voters before an early election.

'We expect more of the same. An electioneering stunt rather than a budget to rebuild our stalling economy and reset the direction of our country,' the top Labour MP said.

Earlier this year, Javid revealed the biggest increase in day-to-day public spending in 15 years

In a short speech earlier this year, Javid announced the biggest increase in day-to-day public spending in 15 years and implied he is prepared to borrow more in the future to take advantage of record-low borrowing costs.

Through a decade of austerity, Britain has shrunk its budget deficit from almost 10 per cent of GDP to just under 2 per cent now.

Public debt has more than doubled since before the financial crisis to more than 80 per cent of GDP.
